Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Assessing the impact of atmospheric observations from Taiwanese aircraft reconnaissance on Typhoon forecasts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate tropical cyclone forecasts are essential for protecting increasingly vulnerable coastal populations worldwide. However, the accuracy of tropical cyclone forecasts relies on high-quality observations used to initialize weather forecast models, and such observations are particularly sparse over the oceans where these intense cyclones spend most of their lives. To alleviate this under-sampling problem for the numerous typhoons threatening Taiwan each year, Dr. Chun-Chieh Wu of National Taiwan University (NTU) established an aircraft reconnaissance program called DOTSTAR. While DOTSTAR aircraft observations have generally improved typhoon forecasts, it remains unclear which types of aircraft observations produce the most significant improvements. In this study conducted in collaboration with Dr. Wu, experimental forecasts incorporating aircraft observations of temperature, humidity, or wind speed will be used to evaluate the relative forecast impact of including each individual type of observation. Better understanding how different aircraft observations affect typhoon forecasts will help optimize future observing missions both in the Pacific and Atlantic basins.

Aircraft observations of tropical cyclones are expensive, and it is therefore beneficial to optimize such missions by better understanding which observations improve forecasts the most. The proposed study will use DOTSTAR dropsonde observations to investigate the relative impact of thermodynamic versus dynamic in situ observations on typhoon structure and intensity forecasts. A series of simulations will be performed using the Weather Research and Forecast (WRF) model with a modern data assimilation system to independently assimilate profiles of temperature, moisture, or winds from DOTSTAR dropsondes for a sample of West Pacific typhoons. In addition, a control simulation without dropsonde observations will be performed. Each simulation will be validated against independent observations, global model reanalysis, and best track datasets to evaluate the improvements resulting from assimilating each subset of dropsonde observations. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate tropical cyclone forecasts are essential for protecting increasingly vulnerable coastal populations worldwide. However, the accuracy of tropical cyclone forecasts relies on high-quality observations used to initialize weather forecast models, and such observations are particularly sparse over the oceans where these intense cyclones spend most of their lives. To alleviate this under-sampling problem for the numerous typhoons threatening Taiwan each year, Professor Chun-Chieh Wu of National Taiwan University (NTU) established an aircraft reconnaissance program known as the Dropwindsonde Observations of Typhoons in the Taiwan Region (DOTSTAR). The DOTSTAR program conducts aircraft missions around typhoons that threaten Taiwan, releasing expendable instruments called dropsondes from the aircraft that measure profiles of wind, temperature, pressure, and humidity on their descent to the surface. While studies have shown that such observations have the ability to improve forecasts of tropical cyclone position and motion, their impacts on tropical cyclone intensity and structure forecasts are not as clear.

This study, which was conducted with Professor Wu in Taiwan as part of the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI), focuses on how the DOTSTAR observations change the model analysis of a selected typhoon. A model analysis refers to the initial conditions from which any weather forecast begins. Previous studies have demonstrated that, in many cases, better analyses lead to better forecasts. The aim of this study is to demonstrate not only the impact of DOTSTAR observations on the analyzed position, intensity, and structure of a selected typhoon, but also to identify the types of DOTSTAR observations that improve analyses the most. To accomplish this, we use a state-of-the-art data assimilation and modeling system to re-analyze Typhoon Tembin (2012). Between 18 and 24 August of 2012, analyses are created every 6 hours from a large set of routine observations covering the West Pacific region, as well as selected subsets of the DOTSTAR dropsonde observations. Four experiments are conducted that include either (1) no DOTSTAR dropsondes; (2) only temperature and pressure profiles; (3) only temperature, pressure, and wind profiles; or (4) all of the available DOTSTAR profiles (temperature, pressure, wind, and humidity).

The analyzed intensity and position of Typhoon Tembin is closer to the estimated intensity and position of the typhoon at almost all analysis times when the DOTSTAR observations are included. While the typhoon in all analyses is too small, those analyses that include DOTSTAR observations tend to have a larger typhoon that is closer to Tembin's estimated size. The wind profile observations have the greatest positive impact on track, intensity, and size, while the pressure and temperature profiles only slightly improve the analyzed fields. The moisture profiles also exhibit positive analysis impact, but to a lesser degree than the wind profiles.

The broader impacts of this research project extend well beyond the potential to improve tropical cyclone observations and forecasts that save lives around the world. During EAPSI in Taiwan, the PI gained significant experience collaborating and working in an international research setting. The unique exposure to the academic culture in Taiwan that EAPSI affords is instrumental in forging fruitful collaborative research partnerships at the host institution, as well as cultivating a new generation of internationally engaged scientists.
